stem_html: If 30.0\,\text{J} are added by heat to water at 12^\circ \text{C}, what is the change in entropy?

answers.content_html: All the spontaneous processes result in decreased total entropy of a system.
answers.feedback_html: The total entropy of a system never decreases in any spontaneous process.

answers.content_html: All the spontaneous processes result in increased total entropy of a system.
answers.feedback_html: The total entropy of a system may also remain constant in some spontaneous processes.

answers.content_html: All the spontaneous processes result in decreased or constant total entropy of a system.
answers.feedback_html: The total entropy of a system can remain the same, but never decreases in any spontaneous process.

answers.content_html: All the spontaneous processes result in increased or constant total entropy of a system.
answers.feedback_html: The total entropy of a system either increases or remains constant in any spontaneous process; it never decreases.

answers.feedback_html: The energy is released as waste heat.
The energy is released as waste heat.
The energy is released as waste heat.
The energy is released as waste heat.

stem_html: In an engine, what is the unused energy converted into?

The wrong formula has been used. Change in entropy is given by \frac{Q}{T}.

stem_html: If Q is 120\,\text{J} and T is 350\,\text{K}, what is the change in entropy?

answers.content_html: Entropy depends on the change of phase of a system, but not on any other state conditions.
answers.feedback_html: Entropy changes whenever there is a transfer of energy by heat, and does not vary only when there is a phase change.

answers.content_html: Entropy does not depend on how the final state is reached from the initial state.
answers.feedback_html: Entropy of a system is a state function, and so does not depend on the path between the initial and final states.

answers.content_html: Entropy is least when the path between the initial state and the final state is the shortest.
answers.feedback_html: Entropy does not increase when the path between the initial and final states is longer than the shortest path.

answers.content_html: Entropy is least when the path between the initial state and the final state is the longest.
answers.feedback_html: The entropy of a system is not a path function.

stem_html: How does the entropy of a system depend on how the system reaches a given state?

answers.feedback_html: The first law states that energy transferred by heat to or from a body changes the internal energy of the body and can be transformed into work done by or on the body.
The second law states that an object at lower temperature does not simultaneously transfer energy by heat to an object at higher temperature.
The third law states that the entropy of a system approaches a constant value (zero) at absolute zero.
The zeroth law states that two bodies at the same temperature are in thermal equilibrium.

stem_html: A cold object in contact with a hot one never spontaneously transfers energy by heat to the hot object. Which law describes this phenomenon?

answers.content_html: Melting converts the highly ordered solid structure into a disorderly liquid, thereby increasing entropy.
answers.feedback_html: The ordered structure of a packed solid transforms into the more random molecular structure of a liquid.

answers.content_html: Melting converts the highly ordered liquid into a disorderly solid structure, thereby increasing entropy.
answers.feedback_html: Liquid structure is not highly ordered.

answers.content_html: Melting converts the highly ordered solid structure into a disorderly solid structure, thereby increasing entropy.
answers.feedback_html: Solid structures are highly ordered, and have low randomness in their molecular structure or motion.

answers.content_html: Melting converts the highly ordered liquid into a disorderly liquid, thereby increasing entropy.
answers.feedback_html: Entropy increases when the randomness in the molecular structure and motions increases.

stem_html: Why does entropy increase when ice melts into water?
